holidays.name: National Pumpkin Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the versatile and beloved pumpkin, from pies to jack-o'-lanterns and everything in between.
holidays.origin: Pumpkins have been a staple in autumn celebrations for centuries, and this day was created to honor their iconic status in fall culture.
holidays.funFact: Did you know the world‚Äôs heaviest pumpkin ever recorded weighed over 2,600 pounds? That‚Äôs enough pumpkin to make a mountain of pies!

holidays.name: Intersex Awareness Day
holidays.description: A day dedicated to raising awareness and promoting human rights for intersex individuals, people born with physical sex characteristics that don‚Äôt fit typical binary notions of male or female bodies.
holidays.origin: Established by intersex activists to increase visibility and combat stigma, it‚Äôs observed annually on October 26.
holidays.funFact: Intersex traits are more common than many think; around 1 in 2,000 babies are born with noticeable intersex characteristics!

holidays.name: Silly Sayings Day
holidays.description: A quirky celebration encouraging people to use, share, and laugh at silly, strange, or old-fashioned sayings and idioms.
holidays.origin: An unofficial holiday that grew popular online as a way to brighten conversations and embrace playful language.
holidays.funFact: Some silly sayings like 'mad as a hatter' come from bizarre historical practices ‚Äî hat makers once used mercury, which made them actually go a bit mad!

holidays.name: National Frankenstein Day
holidays.description: Honoring Mary Shelley‚Äôs groundbreaking gothic novel 'Frankenstein,' a cornerstone of horror literature and pop culture.
holidays.origin: October 26 is the birthday of Mary Shelley, so fans celebrate her work and its enduring creepy charm on this day.
holidays.funFact: Mary Shelley wrote 'Frankenstein' when she was just 18 years old during a ghost-story contest with friends in 1816.
